page.title: 19TEMPLETON'S OLD BUILDINGS.
page.content: Years ago people used to live in pink cottages.They mixed pig's blood with whitewash after a pig killing. There is only one pink cottage left in Templeton. Captain Martin who sailed to the West Indies with Captain Cook lived at Martin's Farm. The Grove Farm was the birthplace of Colonel John Poyer who held Pembroke Castle against Cromwell who later sentenced him to death. Ty Henlloy Cottage used to be the Manse for Molleston Chapel.It is the birthplace of Lord Gordon Parry of Neyland, who was the Chairman of the Wales Tourist Board.His father was the Baptist Minister of Molleston Chapel. Templeton Station still exists but it was closed down in June 1964. By Cleggar's Castle there is a derelict brickworks.
